narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
Mainly virtual seminar, with some individual meetings with the professor and one group-project that required working with other students over Zoom.
1-on-1 meetings over Zoom

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We read some really interesting texts from Anglophone authors around the world, and explored diverse and important themes such as nationhood, race, gender, and the politics of language during and after colonialism. We also discussed critical perspectives on the discipline of world literature.
world literature, writing analytically

My close reading improved a lot by taking this course. Prof. Xiang was amazing at utilizing the breakout rooms to facilitate discussion. One of my new favorite ways to critique a text which was emphasized by her is the way the form of the text informs the text's meaning.

I learned a lot about World Literature and also the problems which are associated with the very idea of a World Literature course. I never considered before this course the idea that World Literature survey courses tend to either be an exploration of a 'civilized' West or an ethnic non-West. This course tended to reject those two options which was incredibly refreshing.
Knowledge of literature from a number of authors of different backgrounds from different points in history
The problem of defining "comparative literature", literary analysis, how to use secondary sources in paper writing,

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the course readings were great and built interestingly on each other.
great professor, good discussions

Strengths: the texts, the discussion (organization with good guiding questions + format over breakout rooms then back as one class), Professor Xiang who is the kindest and most engaged and so fire at leading discussion! Weaknesses: This course is scheduled in OCS as a MWF for 50 minutes, but we only took MW, which I appreciated on one hand because I had no Friday classes. However, I did feel like some of the texts could have used more time. In particular, we barely discussed Kincaid's Autobiography of My Mother. I think this is because of other scheduling differences, but apparently this course ran slower than it would have in a normal in-person year, and I don't see how the discussions could go as in depth as they needed to at a faster pace. I say this because even though I loved our discussions, I always felt like we ran out of time or just didn't have the time to go as in depth as we could/should have. I either wish we had taken the Friday classes or the schedule would have been a little better to accommodate the texts, especially as the semester went on (so Kincaid and laterand also especially the Oceania texts). Related, I loved our initial ice breakers, but especially with people coming in late over Zoom, the ice breakers would often take up to or even over 10 minutes of our class time, which could be frustrating when then we didn't have ample time to discuss.

Strengths: a clear understanding of the limitations of a "World English Literature" course that aptly named and discussed the tensions that existed; exposure to different pieces of literature; having speakers come in and discuss various works with us; extensive opportunity for feedback on essays

Seminar format is very good. Reading list was a bit hit or miss but generally good. Some books felt a bit rushed. Could be improved with one or two fewer books to allow for deeper dives into other books
Strengths: the unique syllabus, the organization of paper assignments, class sessions with guest speakers, the focus on collective participation, Professor Xiang

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought Professor Xiang did a wonderful job with the Zoom format. Her icebreakers and focus on collective participation helped build community and create a comfortable discussion environment.

The breakout rooms were awesome. Prof. Xiang was my only professor who I think truly mastered the online situation. I got the sense that she was being inventive and not just doing the same thing but over Zoom. With our breakout discussions, normally she would give us context as a big class then send a file with questions into the chat, then divide us up. Then we would have 15-20 minutes to discuss and then come back and discuss as a class.

I really appreciated Professor Xiang engaging us in thinking about what course participation might look like in a time like this. It created a welcoming environment that strived for high standards of education while still acknowledging that things were not quite the same. Use of synchronous and asynchronous pieces together (the seminars, individual study, and discussion boards) kept students engaged throughout the week, not just during those few zoom sessions. And the icebreakers! how could we not mention the icebreakers! were also a fun way to get to know each other, although sometimes they took a bit long for our 50 minutes sessions. I think the Worlding Project was an interesting project, and should be iterated upon if it is to be kept. It felt a little...detached from the rest of the course, and having a little more guidance on what the focus of the project was would be good.
Breakout groups worked well
I normally don't enjoy breakout rooms, but I think they worked in this course and helped us feel more connected despite the remote format.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I really enjoyed the course readings and discussions. It felt interesting and important to consider the legacy of colonialism through literature, and to think critically about the way world English literature is defined.

I would definitely recommend to another student! My foremost reason is because of Prof. Xiang, but I also think the novels we read were interesting by themselves. I also loved the open-ended paper topics, so I felt like I really learned through writing my papers. The writing center partner Taylor Adams was AMAZING as well. Having that explicit resource was so helpful for out of class writing.
Absolutely! Especially with Professor Xiang. She is incredible.
A good English class for major and nonmajors. Not too much work or reading but still a high level of engagement.
Absolutely.
